perturbation.original_text: PageMaster Corporation in conjunction with Go Call, shall offer free new Motorola "Wordline Alphanumeric" (or equal) pagers with no activation fee to all customers responding to this promotion who purchase twelve (12) months of numeric paging and airtime products and services from PageMaster Corporation ("Purchase Customers").
perturbation.changed_text: PageMaster Corporation in conjunction with Go Call, shall offer free new Motorola "Wordline Alphanumeric" (or equal) pagers with no activation fee to all consumers responding to this promotion who purchase twelve (12) months of numeric paging and airtime products and services from PageMaster Corporation ("Subscribers").
perturbation.explanation: The term 'Purchase Customers' is replaced with 'Subscribers'. Throughout the agreement, it is now unclear whether 'Purchase Customers' and 'Subscribers' refer to the same group, potentially leading to confusion regarding eligibility for the promotion and related obligations. This introduces a discrepancy that may lead to disputes.

perturbation.original_text: PageMaster Corporation shall pay to Go Call, Co-Op Marketing funds for the promotion. PageMaster Corporation will pay Go Call $3.00 per pager (beginning with pager # 1) and 5% of all airtime renewal revenue for each pager redeemed for this promotion consistent with the terms of paragraph 6b of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: PageMaster Corporation shall remit to Go Call, Co-Op Marketing funds for the promotion. PageMaster Corporation will pay Go Call $3.00 per pager (beginning with pager # 1) and 5% of all airtime renewal revenue for each pager redeemed for this promotion consistent with the terms of paragraph 6b of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The term 'pay' is interchanged with the term 'remit'. This introduces confusion regarding the mode and timing of payments from PageMaster Corporation to Go Call. The term 'pay' can entail the standard meaning, whereas the term 'remit' carries a connotation of deferring a payment. The interchange can lead to ambiguity and financial disagreements.

perturbation.original_text:
Any notice or demand given to either party under the Terms of this Agreement or pursuant to statute shall be in writing and shall be given or made by telegram, facsimile transmission, certified or registered mail, express mail or other overnight delivery service or hand delivery, proper postage or other charges prepaid and addressed or directed to the respective parties as follows:
PAGEMASTER CORPORATION 100 E. Thousand Oaks Blvd. Suite 297 Thousand Oaks, CA 91360 ATTN:    Marc Resnick, CEO
GO CALL, INC. 15 Queen Street East Cambridge Ontario, Canada N3C2A7 ATTN:    Ian Smith, President
Such notice or demand shall be deemed to have been given or made when actually received or seventy-two (72) hours after being sent, whichever occurs first. The address for notice set out above may be changed at any time by giving thirty (30) days prior written notice in the manner above.
perturbation.changed_text:
Any notice or demand given to either party under the Terms of this Agreement or pursuant to statute shall be in writing and shall be given or made by telegram, facsimile transmission, certified or registered mail, express mail or other overnight delivery service or hand delivery, proper postage or other charges prepaid and addressed or directed to the respective parties as follows:
PAGEMASTER CORPORATION 100 E. Thousand Oaks Blvd. Suite 297 Thousand Oaks, CA 91360 ATTN:    Marc Resnick, CEO
GO CALL, INC. 15 Queen Street East Cambridge Ontario, Canada N3C2A7 ATTN:    Ian Smith, President
Such notice or demand shall be considered to have been given or made when actually received or seventy-two (72) hours after being sent, whichever occurs first. The address for notice set out above may be changed at any time by giving thirty (30) days prior written notice in the manner above.
perturbation.explanation: The term 'deemed' is interchanged with the term 'considered'. The substitution creates an inconsistency that could be used to argue that 'deemed' is a legal definition and therefore final while 'considered' leaves more room for interpretation. The term 'deemed' implies a legal assumption regardless of actual facts, while the term 'considered' suggests a more discretionary assessment. This can create uncertainty when determining the effective date of notices and demands under the agreement, leading to potential disputes over compliance deadlines.
